items.title: Canada tops Finland to claim bronze at world junior hockey championship
items.summary_auto: Zayne Parekh had a goal and an assist to set a new record for points by a Canadian defenceman at a world junior hockey championship as the country salvaged a bronze medal with a 6-3 victory over Finland on Monday.

items.title: With Olympics near, return to full health trumps potential milestone win for Mikaël Kingsbury
items.summary_auto: Canadian freestyle skier and reigning Olympic silver medallist Mikaël Kingsbury says he's nearing full health from a left groin injury while preparing for a return to World Cup moguls this week in Val St-Côme, Que.

items.title: World leaders push back against U.S. in wake of Maduro's ouster
items.summary_auto: Leaders in Greenland, Mexico and Colombia are asserting their respective nations' sovereignty and pushing back on pressure from Washington after it removed Nicolás Maduro from power in Venezuela over the weekend.

items.title: Venezuelans wait anxiously as their country's future hangs in the balance, says resident
items.summary_auto: A strange lull has taken over the capital of Venezuela as people wait to find out what the future holds for their country, says Caracas resident Benigno Alarcón Deza.

items.title: Lawsuit alleges 3 Denny’s workers in Kamloops, B.C., misappropriated $500K in tips
items.summary_auto: A civil suit filed in the Supreme Court of B.C. accuses three Denny's workers of misappropriating more than $500,000 in tips from the restaurant chain while working at a Kamloops location between 2023 and 2025.

items.title: Uncertainty looms in Cuba after the capture of president of Venezuela, Cuba's closest ally
items.summary_auto: Cuban officials on Monday lowered flags before dawn to mourn 32 security officers they say were killed in the U.S. weekend strike in Venezuela, Cuba's closest ally, as residents of the island nation wonder what the capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro means for their future.

items.title: Impaired drivers in Ontario face automatic, harsher penalties under new rules now in effect
items.summary_auto: New rules and increased penalties for impaired driving took effect this month across Ontario, after the province made amendments to the Highway Traffic Act. Advocacy groups say more can be done to curb impaired drivers, but overall, the changes are positive.

items.title: Rare prosecution of a police officer gets underway in connection to Uvalde, Texas, school shooting
items.summary_auto: A former school police officer in Uvalde, Texas, who was part of the slow law enforcement response to one of the worst school shootings in U.S. history went on trial Monday on charges that he failed to protect children from the gunman.

items.title: Canadian energy stocks tumble after U.S. incursion in Venezuela
10 people found guilty of cyberbullying French first lady Brigitte Macron
items.summary_auto: A Paris court has found 10 people guilty of cyberbullying France's first lady, Brigitte Macron, by spreading false online claims about her gender and sexuality, including allegations that she was born male.

items.title: Unions, public service employees speak out against Ontario return to office policy
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s mandate for government employees to return to office five days a week has kicked in starting Monday, much to the dismay of unions and public service workers.

items.title: Ottawa's Rideau Canal Skateway fully opens
items.summary_auto: The National Capital Commission opened the entire length of the Rideau Canal Skateway on Monday morning. CBC's Sannah Choi spoke with some of the first people to skate it.

items.title: Tim Walz scraps Minnesota re-election campaign amid state fraud scandals
items.summary_auto: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz is ending his bid for a third term, less than four months after announcing his reelection campaign. Walz was the Democratic vice-presidential nominee during the 2024 election campaign.

items.title: Former OHL commissioner, CHL president David Branch dead at 77
items.summary_auto: Former Ontario Hockey League commissioner and Canadian Hockey League president David Branch has died. He was 77. The OHL and Canadian Hockey League announced his death Monday, stating he died Sunday. No cause of death was revealed.

items.title: Tangled cars and billowing smoke: Hinton remembers deadly rail disaster 40 years later
items.summary_auto: Colin Hanington followed a plume of smoke to reach one of the deadliest railway crashes in Canadian history, and almost 40 years later remembers the silence when he got there.

items.title: Who is Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela's new interim leader?
items.summary_auto: Delcy Rodríguez, at least for now, has taken over as leader of Venezuela after her ally Nicolás Maduro was seized by the United States to face criminal indictment in New York. With the events from Maduro's stunning capture still fresh, there are more questions than answers about Rodríguez's future dealings with the U.S.

items.title: Former Winnipeg police officer pleads guilty to selling drugs — including to other officers
items.summary_auto: A former Winnipeg police officer who previously pleaded guilty to a long list of charges involving corruption and other inappropriate actions has now also admitted to selling drugs over a period of years — both to civilians and other police officers.

items.title: 'Hands off Venezuela,' say protesters at Ontario rally following U.S. action against Maduro
Quebec students return to class as new civility rules come into effect
items.summary_auto: In a bid to improve student behaviour in Quebec schools, new rules are now in effect requiring students to use formal language when addressing teachers and school staff.

items.title: B.C. cities say they're on the hook for millions for housing, social issues due to senior gov't 'downloading'
items.summary_auto: B.C. municipalities have long complained senior levels of government have “downloaded” costs and responsibilities onto them. Now some cities have tried to quantify how much they’ve taken on — and they say it could cost them millions.

items.title: 'A whirlwind journey': Sit-skier Kurt Oatway’s fight to return to the Paralympics
items.summary_auto: At age 41, Kurt Oatway shows a steely determination to fight his way back to the top of the world stage after a devastating ski crash left him severely injured and forced to watch the 2022 Beijing Games at home.

items.title: Freeland to step down in 'coming weeks' after accepting role advising Ukraine's Zelenskyy
items.summary_auto: Longtime Liberal Chrystia Freeland says she'll step down as a member of Parliament in the "coming weeks" after accepting a new role advising Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

items.title: ‘A no-brainer’: Why some U.S. health-care workers are moving to Nova Scotia
items.summary_auto: Nova Scotia Health says 50 American health-care workers have taken positions in Nova Scotia in the past fiscal year, up from 31 in 2024.

items.title: Visa processing error by IRCC forces Halifax international student to stop studying, working
items.summary_auto: An international student at Dalhousie University in Halifax is raising issues with Canada’s immigration process after she had to stop studying and working because of a visa processing error.

items.title: Cars crash into London buildings 5 times a month on average, new numbers show
items.summary_auto: Numbers from London, Ont., police show 47 vehicles crashed into buildings in both the years 2023 and 2024, and 50 by October 2025.

items.title: Canadian airlines could be forced to 'up their game' as Ottawa allows more competition from Middle East
items.summary_auto: Airlines in Canada could be under pressure soon to improve their services as the federal government opens up its skies to more competition from the Middle East.

items.title: She was forced to travel hours to give birth — a growing reality for families in Gaspé, Que.
items.summary_auto: Expectant mothers in the Gaspé are frequently redirected to hospitals hours away to give birth, and some are warning the situation may grow even worse if the province doesn't intervene.

items.title: Thunder Bay, Ont. university piloting walk that brings 9,000 years of local history to life
items.summary_auto: Lakehead University is testing a new Two-Eyed Seeing walk that guides participants through Indigenous history, culture and reconciliation on its Thunder Bay campus

items.title: Ontario will hold firm on U.S. booze ban at LCBO, says finance minister
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s finance minister says nothing short of full removal of tariffs will bring U.S. booze back to LCBO shelves, doubling-down on a trade irritant that has continued to frustrate President Donald Trump’s administration.

items.title: Carney heads to Paris as allies discuss security guarantees for Ukraine
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney is headed to Paris where he will meet with "coalition of the willing" partners to talk about specific security guarantees for Ukraine should there be a ceasefire and peace settlement with Russia.

items.title: This Canadian explorer dove under the North Pole, discovered shipwrecks and helped a Hollywood director
items.summary_auto: From the Arctic to the Titanic, 88-year-old Joe MacInnis reflects on the dives and discoveries that instilled in him humility and awe for the ocean.
